content.description:
Short, but very sustained climb on a beautiful piece of overhanging granite in a pleasant forest setting.

Stand up on the ledge to clip the first bolt and then fire off a sequence of progressively harder, bouldery moves to the top.

The climb is given 12d in the 2017 North Tahoe guidebook, but a key foot broke at the beginning of the crux around the 3rd bolt and the upgrade to 13a seems fair. Very much a roped boulder problem, so your opinion on the grade may vary.
content.location: Obvious line up the center of the overhanging face that the leaning tree rests on.

content.description: Great finger crack going straight up the vertical face of the leaning tree wall. Surprisingly sustained and varied in movement. Meets up with the left crack line at a big hole in the middle and finishes with some easier but non-trivial movement to the anchors or an easy mantle and walk-off.
content.protection:
Single rack to 1", double to 0.5", rap anchor.

A toprope can be setup very easily and cleanly by walking around the left of the crag.
content.location: Rightmost of the two cracks on the clean vertical face right of the leaning tree.

content.description: Nice, thin crack that has good variety in movement. Not as sustained as its neighbor, but with much more devious crux moves. Starts with some more straightforward moves and good laybacks until the big feet run out. Some delicate foot movement and a careful choice of hands will see you through the crux to a decent rest hold (that was quite wet in the early summer). One more balancy move is required to meet up with the right crack in the big hole and finish off with some easier movement to the top.
content.protection:
Single rack to 1", double to 0.75", rap anchor.

A toprope can be setup very easily and cleanly by walking around the left of the crag.
content.location: Left of the two cracks on the vertical face right of the leaning tree.

content.description:
A method of pre-clipping the high first bolt is required to make this a pure sport climb. Either use a long stick clip or pre-place the draws from above.

Mostly easy climbing with two, quick, burly cruxes between the first and second, and second and third bolts. The cruxes both involve some pretty funky arête movement, with poor feet and hands.

Most of the climb is pretty dirty at the time of writing, and would benefit from quite a bit more traffic and cleaning.
content.protection:
3 bolts to a two-bolt anchor with quicklinks and one rap ring. Gear to 0.75" can be used to protect the moves below the high first bolt, otherwise use a long stick clip or pre-place from above.

Though a toprope can be setup easily by walking around the left side of the crag, the rope will rub quite a bit on the top ledges if the anchor is not extended significantly (~10 feet).
content.location: Arête between the steep face of the leaning tree to the left and the vertical face to the right.

content.description:
Slightly overhanging and thin crack with a crux about halfway up, getting past a couple of shitty jams. Above, the route moves into a funky stem/flare and the difficulties ease quite a bit.

This thing climbs well as-is but is still fairly dirty. I cleaned it a fair bit but it could use some traffic and would be better for it.
content.location: Thin crack to the right of Tube Steak Boogie (look for the fixed draws).

content.description: Follow the right-leaning, crack-to-seam system. Burly laybacking and underclinging from the 3rd bolt to the anchors.
content.location: Furthest left route on the wall. Shares the last bolt and anchors with Tube Steak Boogie.
